0.text: Hey, welcome to the Fizzl 360 degree tour of London!

4.text: My name is Reid - I'll be your tour guide for today.

7.text: Even though I personally have never been to London...

12.text: But hey, they pay me! So, from my basement in Ridgewood, Queens -

16.text: You buckled in? Alright ya big travelling goofs! Let's go to London town...

24.text: Actually... no, this is Tower Bridge.

26.text: Black Eyed Peas' Fergie got that wrong in her solo song... cover... photo thing.

32.text: This is not London Bridge, ok? This is a bridge, in London.. Actually it is kinda confusing!

38.text: There's an absolute replica of this bridge in China, but that one's just got a coffee shop in it.

43.text: But this one - this one here - this is it.

48.text: This ol' bridge took eight years to build and was completed in 1894.

54.text: Before that, people walked through a long tunnel under the Thames below us.

56.text: I bet that stank down there!

59.text: The walkway under the Towers used to be a haunt for prostitutes and thieves,

65.text: It was opened back up in 1982, so I'm gonna go ahead and

67.text: assume all these people are NOT prostitutes or thieves.

73.text: Actually, 40,000 people cross the bridge every day so if, y'know, that's something you were gonna do,

77.text: not a bad place to set up shop.

82.text: It opens up; it lets boats through.

84.text: In 1952, the Bridge started to open with a double-decker bus halfway across.

89.text: The driver, good old Albert Gunter,

92.text: accelerated real fast and leapt across the 3 foot gap.

95.text: He got a £10 reward for his bravery.

97.text: Which... is not that much, for jumping a bus.

100.text: I mean, c'mon - Sandra Bullock got plenty more for 'Speed'.

103.text: Anyways, ships always get the right of way.

106.text: Bill Clinton found that out the hard way in 1997,

109.text: when his motorcade was split into two by a sailing barge called Gladys.

113.text: Honk honk! Out of the way, leader of the free world - I'm doing me some sailin...

122.text: Hold on to your hats. Or fanny packs; I don't know what kinda travellers we got here.

130.text: Just down this way is the Tower of London.

134.text: Calm down, sir. Don't lose your head!

137.text: Ah, see what I did there...?

139.text: Behind you is the River Thames, of course.

142.text: That weird pointy building is called the Shard,

145.text: and to the left of it is where the Mayor of London does all his Mayor-ing.

150.text: This old castle was built by William the Conqueror in 1066.

153.text: I mean, I doubt he did it all on his own, he probably had a crew of dudes.

157.text: It's been an armoury, a Royal Mint, a zoo and a royal residence.

161.text: Imagine living in the Tower of London!

163.text: "Hey girl, wanna come back to my tower castle thing...

168.text: Its first prisoner was actually the former constable of the Tower itself, Bishop Flambard.

172.text: He also become the first escapee in 1100.

175.text: Wonder where ol' Flambard is now?

178.text: Guy Fawkes was brought here after he tried to blow up the Houses of Parliament in 1605.

182.text: He's why Brits let off fireworks every November 5th.

184.text: Which is a thing they do that I learned just now.

187.text: Anne Boleyn, big fat Henry the Eigth's wife

190.text: had a stint here as well. Which, as you might know, did not go well.

195.text: So, y'know how when you think of the Tower of London, you think of heads being cut off?

199.text: Well actually, only 22 executions ever happened here.

202.text: The last man to be beheaded here was in 1747,

205.text: after the viewing platform collapsed, killing 20 spectators.

209.text: That'll teach you to go watch beheadings, ya sickos.

213.text: Ready to move on kids? Ok, you big old goofballs!

222.text: Here we are at BuckingHAM Palace.

226.text: Someone told me once that Americans put too much emphasis on the 'ham' part of that word,

229.text: so, y'know, you could pronounce it 'Buckingumm'. Now you're a Londoner, real cool.

234.text: This is where Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second lives.

238.text: And judging by the flag moving above the building, it looks like she's at home today.

243.text: Just hanging out in her 775 rooms.

247.text: That includes 52 royal and guest bedrooms,

257.text: There's a whole lotta digesting going on there.

259.text: It was built in 1705 as the townhouse for the Duke of Buckingham,

263.text: who must have been seriously fancy.

266.text: And of course, it's name after him. Typical Duke.

270.text: It's been the official residence of the monarch since 1837

273.text: after George the Third paid £21,000 for it.

276.text: That's about $4.5 million, Kanye West. In case you're interested.

282.text: During World War Two, King George the Sixth and his wife Elizabeth, the current Queen's late mommy,

286.text: refused to leave the palace, which meant that the Germans - well, they understandably wanted to bomb the complete crap out of it.

294.text: But the Royals said that everybody remained wonderfully calm.

297.text: A sentence that probably itself reeked of gin.

301.text: Oh hey, look on the other side of the palace!

303.text: There is a big old gold statue over there, and that's the Queen Victoria Memorial.

308.text: It marks the death of that little grumpy queen in 1901.

312.text: Not sure I'd like to look out of my bedroom window every morning and be reminded that my grandmother is dead.

316.text: But hey, do you think they even look out the windows?

322.text: Alright my internet friends, lets go hit a cathedral.

326.text: Welcome to St. Paul's Cathedral; Sir Christopher Wren's masterpiece.

332.text: Everyone loves that big dome-y guy.

335.text: You know what, you can actually go inside and get up into that dome.

339.text: Which by the way it's the second largest dome in the entire world...

341.text: ..the first one being a dome that I still don't know the name of.

345.text: I don't know a lot about domes.

347.text: You can actually get up inside of that dome to a place called the Whispering Gallery.

352.text: If you whisper on one side, a fellow way over on the other side - 112 feet away - can hear you.

357.text: Until 1962, this was the tallest building in all of London.

361.text: Now it is.... not. By like miles.

365.text: Did you know Lord Horatio Nelson is buried under the Cathedral?

369.text: I know! I always thought he was at the top of Nelson's Column.

373.text: But hey, what do I know? I'm just a fella in a basement in Queens.

378.text: Loads of big stuff happened at St. Paul's.

380.text: In 1964, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered a sermon.

389.text: In 1981, Prince Charles and Lady Diana got hitched here.

393.text: In 2011, their son William married Kate.

397.text: And it's not just all plain church-ing for St. Paul's either.

400.text: The Great Fire of London burned it up pretty rough.

403.text: In World War Two it basically sat there, just showin' German planes where to bomb.

407.text: Hey bombs! Hit my big fat dome!

413.text: But one bomb was retrieved before it actually went off.

415.text: Otherwise, it probably would have been completely destroyed.

419.text: Alright, are we all church-ed out?

427.text: This, my friends, is Parliament Square.

429.text: Directly in front of you is the Palace of Westminster, or 'Parliament'

432.text: a fantasy gothic palace that was built on the site of William The Conqueror's first palace.

436.text: It was built in the 1840s and has over 1100 rooms,

439.text: and those rooms are now where all that British political stuff goes on.

445.text: Big Ben is the most famous part, of course.

447.text: Ben is actually the name for the huge bell inside the Tower.

450.text: The Tower itself is named the 'Elizabeth Tower'.

453.text: Apparently the clock's mechanism is regulated by adding pennies for weight.

460.text: Oh, there it goes! The bell's going off!

462.text: Hi Big Ben, nice to meet you. You don't need to shout at me.

466.text: All sorts of Britishness goes on in there. And by that, I mean antiquated nonsense.

471.text: You know the elevators have hooks for hanging your sword? Imagine that in your mall...

475.text: In the cloakroom, there's purple ribbon attached to every coat hanger - and that's also for swords.

480.text: Apparently, there's one politician that still does that. Y'know, brings a sword to work with him.

486.text: Like a real adult. Living in a not-fantasy.

490.text: The main debating, or arguing chamber is called the House of Commons,

494.text: and this is where all the regional politicians assemble to make grunting noises,

498.text: call each other 'the Right Honourable Member',

500.text: and sometimes take peaceful little naps.

503.text: Monarchs aren't actually allowed to enter this chamber. At all.

506.text: In fact, it actually hasn't happened since King Charles the First stormed in here

509.text: and arrested five Members for treason.

512.text: The Civil War happened right after that; it didn't really make him popular.

515.text: It was kind of a.... d*** move, you might say.

518.text: You must not swear inside here,

522.text: Do not do it, otherwise you will "offend the dignity of Parliament".

525.text: So for sure do not say something like:

528.text: [series of comedy bleeped out swear words]

536.text: Let's go look at a man on top of a big column.

544.text: Hey Horatio! How ya hanging my man?

547.text: [laughs] That's just a lil' joke we have.

552.text: So this is Lord Horatio Nelson and this is Trafalgar Square, welcome to it.

558.text: He's a whole 196 feet and 3 inches up.

560.text: Not compensating for anything, for sure.

563.text: He's decorated with four bronze panels that were actually cast from captured French guns

567.text: during the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805.

570.text: You know, if Hitler won World War Two

572.text: he planned to relocate Nelson's Column to Berlin.

575.text: We're actually standing on a small traffic island on the south of the Square.

578.text: Have you ever heard of Charing Cross? It's a train station; it's just down the road.

582.text: But this very spot is actually the REAL Charing Cross.

585.text: And it's from this exact place that all distances from London are calculated.

589.text: So when you see a sign somewhere that says: "You are approximately 3 billion miles from London"...

595.text: ..I don't know where you are, but well this is the spot it's talking about.

599.text: It's just the most London-y spot there is.

602.text: The four famous bronze lions around the Square have been since 1868.

606.text: Creator Edwin Lanseer actually worked from real lion corpses to make 'em.

612.text: A guy name Thomas Milnes originally had a go at making the lions.

616.text: He made them out of stone, but they weren't good enough apparently.

619.text: So he sold them and sent them up north to a village called Saltaire,

627.text: You got to see a little bit of London.

629.text: You got to hear my voice, which maybe annoyed you... I don't know how you feel about me.

635.text: I've been Reid, I was your tour guide. Have a pleasant day.
